title: Nixtun Chʼichʼ
text:
Nixtun-Chʼichʼ is an <a href="Itza%20people">Itza</a> <a href="Maya%20civilization">Maya</a> <a href="archaeological%20site">archaeological site</a> in <a href="Pet%C3%A9n%20Department">Petén Department</a>, <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>. It has an urban grid with fairly well ordered streets and avenues dated to around 2500 years ago. This is one of the earliest urban grids in the <a href="Americas">Americas</a> and likely emerged as the ancient <a href="Maya%20civilization">Maya</a> developed more complex forms of <a href="Political%20organisation">political organization</a>. It was likely a means to regulate and perhaps dominate the <a href="Residency%20%28domicile%29">inhabitants</a>. Nevertheless, the <a href="Grid%20plan">grid system</a> at Nixtun-Chʼichʼ did not catch on and is not seen in later <a href="Maya%20civilization">Maya</a> cities.
Location.
Nixtun-Chʼichʼ stands on the western edge of <a href="Lake%20Pet%C3%A9n%20Itz%C3%A1">Lake Petén Itzá</a>. It is bordered by the <a href="lake">lake</a> to the <a href="south">south</a> and <a href="east">east</a>; by <a href="karst">karst</a>ic hills to the north; and uneven terrain to the west. The area of the site is relatively flat, but it was built upon a low <a href="ridge">ridge</a> that extends east to west. <a href="Maya%20civilization">Maya</a> sites are generally dispersed, but Nixtun-Chʼichʼ was laid out with an <a href="Urban%20area">urban</a> grid. It also includes an "axis urbis" composed of a row of over 15 buildings extending east to west. The axis and grid were established in the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Middle Preclassic period</a> (800-400 BC). The site also has major construction in the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Late Preclassic period</a> (400 BC-AD 200) after which the site appears to have suffered a decline—a trend seen in many sites in central <a href="Pet%C3%A9n%20Department">Petén</a>. The site was also occupied in the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Late Classic through the Colonial period</a> (AD 600-1734).
Preclassic period.
During the 1995, 2006-2008, and 2013-2014 seasons at Nixtun-Chʼich, Proyecto <a href="Itza%20people">Itza</a> encountered <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Preclassic period</a> (ca.1000 BC-AD 200) constructions in nearly every test unit <a href="Excavation%20%28archaeology%29">excavate</a>d. It was clear that the site's most substantial constructions occurred before AD 200. In 2013-2014, Proyecto <a href="Itza%20people">Itza</a> remapped the site and found that it contained an <a href="Urban%20area">urban</a> grid. In 2015, Proyecto <a href="Itza%20people">Itza</a> began to intensively investigate the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Preclassic period</a> occupations along with its work on the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Postclassic period</a>.
Late postclassic and colonial period.
<a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Postclassic and Colonial period</a> <a href="Human%20settlement">settlements</a> have been found at Nixtun-Chʼichʼ in Sector QQ (<a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Middle to Late Postclassic period</a>), Sector WW (<a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Middle to Late Postclassic period</a>), Sector XX (<a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Contact or Colonial period</a>), and Sector ZZ (<a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Colonial period</a>). See map below.
Underwater Archaeology.
In 2015, Proyecto <a href="Itza%20people">Itza</a> initiated a program of <a href="underwater%20archaeology">underwater archaeology</a> on <a href="Lake%20Pet%C3%A9n%20Itz%C3%A1">Lake Petén Itzá</a> and began sampling in 2018. The goal of this work is to discern deposits in the lake left as offerings or accidentally dropped into the lake as a result of trade. Proyecto Itza has identified several areas that "look like" <a href="port">port</a>s at Nixtun-Chʼichʼ and we will test this hypothesis though underwater <a href="Sampling%20%28statistics%29">sampling</a>.
Nixtun Chʼichʼ documentary.
In 2017, Proyecto <a href="Itza%20people">Itza</a> began filming a <a href="Documentary%20film">documentary</a> about the development of <a href="Urban%20planning">city planning</a> and the state at Nixtun-Chʼichʼ.
